title: Form Checkboxes
reference-overview: Check boxes are form elements that allow users to make specific selections from a set of alternatives. More than one checkbox can be selected at time and a checkbox can be preselected by default. Use subheads to break up a long list of checkboxes into logical groups. This makes the choices faster to scan and easier to understand. And in those cases you may want to use Selected Checkbox.
reference-usage: Check boxes are used when you want to let the user select one or more options from a set of options. If only one option is to be selected at a time you should use radio buttons instead.
reference-details:
When a checkox is initially selected the Active State (see below) is highlighted using the "Attention" color and a checkmark is added to the box.

Margins

In order to keep with Mercer consistency, the margins between Elements have been standardized:

  • Use a 10 pixel bottom between the Element and next Field Label.
  • Use a 3 pixel bottom margin between a Label and an Input.

Labels

All field labels should use Title Case. See the Copy/Text Style Guide narrative for more detail.

Active State

The active state for any field should be indicated by the application of the "Attention" color to the border of the specific field the user has clicked into. See Color Palette for more details on "Attention" color.

Required Fields

All required fields should be denoted by placing the Required icon (the evo-asterisk-small icon from the list of icons) immediately to the left of the Field Label.

Error Handling

See the Field Specific Error Message page for details.
reference-mobile:
The font size will increase slightly.

The field label will stack on top of the checkbox options.
